items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
This is an opportunity for members of the public to address the Board concerning issues not listed on the agenda.
	 
The Board welcomes this opportunity to hear from the public and has established a policy for the public's participation in board meetings, which is outlined in BP 2345. This policy states that:
	 
No member of the public may speak without being recognized by the President of the Board.
Each speaker will be allowed a maximum of three minutes per topic. Thirty minutes shall be the maximum time allotment for public speakers on any one subject regardless of the number of speakers at any one Board meeting. At the discretion of a majority of the Board, these time limits may be extended.
The Board recognizes the need to encourage public participation but also recognizes the need to preserve order and the proper functioning of the meeting. Citizens addressing the Board at meetings shall therefore conduct themselves at all times in a manner appropriate to the setting.

items.item_details:
On May 26, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Taber Construction, Inc. in the amount of $7,115,000 to provide construction services for the Central Green / Arts Plaza Project #32116 at Evergreen Valley College.
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District requested design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 002 includes revisions to the Gullo Pathway to correct Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) slope compliance issues provide drainage and revise adjacent landscaping and irrigation, correct existing drainage and ADA compliance issues at the exterior Visual Arts staircase, replace existing damaged storm drain and telecom manhole covers and adjust concrete walkways at the PE building, revisions to storm drain inlets and grates in the Arts Plaza to correct slope and ADA compliance issues, a credit to remove the asphalt slurry seal from the project due to weather issues, installation of 36” box trees at the Arts Plaza bioswales which were not able to be relocated due to unforeseen utility conflicts, repairs to Arts Plaza backflow preventer area and loading dock area hardscape to correct existing safety issues, repairs to existing irrigation wiring and piping in areas adjacent to the project which prevented new irrigation work from operating correctly, relocation of two recycled water main lines at the Arts Plaza which were not shown on existing as-built documents and were in conflict with new bio-swales, removal of 300 lineal feet of transite pipe which was not known at the beginning of the project, and exceeded the costs of the project allowance for this scope of work, extending electrical and telecom conduits, cable trays and wiring inside the new Main Data Frame (MDF) which will allow connectivity to new electrical work for the Central Green, and installation of handrail at the Arts Plaza to meet ADA code which was not included in contract documents.
	 
	 
	 
Taber Construction Inc. submitted written pricing proposals for these changes (details in the Agenda attachment) that include the applicable increase or decrease in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                 $7,115,000.00
Previous Approved Changes                            $   219,768.00
Change Order No. 002                                     $   196,575.00
Total Contract and Changes                             $7,531,343.00
	 
The net change to Taber Construction, Inc.’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $416,343 which equates to 5.85% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change. 
	 
The Substantial Completion Date remains January 1, 2016, and will be adjusted with the final change order, which is anticipated in March 2016.

items.item_details:
The scope of the Hydronic Piping Equipment Upgrade Project includes demolishing the existing cooling tower treatment system and 15000MT chemical inhibitor containment tank.  Replacement of the existing chemical pot feeders on chilled water and heating hot water closed loop systems, providing and installing chilled water closed loop filter, pot feeder and all corresponding piping to existing heating hot water system. 
	 
The project was posted on the District’s purchasing website and advertised in local papers on January 7, 2016 and January 14, 2016.  It was published at local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 90 contractors including small minority and woman-owned firms.  On February 5, 2016 construction bids were received as follows:
	 
Cal West                                            $   78,000.00
O.C. McDonald                                  $   91,437.00
ESI                                                     $ 112,000.00
	 
Cal West Construction from Gilroy, California was determined to have the lowest cost bid for the project, however it was noted when bids were opened that Cal West’s bid package contained irregularities which preclude it from being considered the lowest responsive and responsible bidder.  Irregularities included the omission of the Construction Careers Program Agreement (Appendix  A & B), as well as submission of the bid bond in an incorrect format with language that does not match District Standards.  O.C. McDonald Company, Inc. of San Jose, California was determined to be the second lowest responsive and responsible bidder in the amount of 91,437.00. 
	 
Therefore it is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and award the contract with O.C. McDonald Company, Inc. in the amount of $91,437.00 for the Hydronic Piping Equipment Upgrade at Evergreen Community College.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees reject the CalWest bid as non-responsive, and approve the Agreement in the amount of $91,437.00 to O.C. McDonald Company, Inc. for bid #G2010.0112 - Hydronic Piping Equipment Upgrade Project at Evergreen Valley College.

items.item_details:
Proposition 39, which governs the District’s general obligation bonds, requires the establishment of a citizens’ oversight committee.  Following the passage of Measure G-2004 on November 2, 2004, the Board of Trustees took action on May 10, 2005 to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee.  Measure G-2010 was passed by the voters on November 2, 2010, after which the Board of Trustees took action on December 14, 2010 to amend and restate the bylaws to allow for the existing committee to support both Measure G-2004 and Measure G-2010.
	 
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) is required by statute to meet at least annually to review the District’s Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 bond projects plan and to ensure that bond funds are being appropriately used as authorized by the voters.  There are no penalties defined in law for failure to convene a citizens’ oversight committee; however, the spirit of the law contemplates that districts will make every reasonable effort to ensure that the committee functions at least once each year to fulfill its statutory duties.  The current CBOC convenes quarterly for meetings.
	 
Pursuant to Proposition 39, the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee 
is required to have a minimum of seven (7) members comprised of one (1) student active in a community college support group, such as student government, two (2) Community-At-Large members, one (1) Senior Citizens’ Organization member, one (1) Business Community member, one (1) Bona-fide Tax Payers’ Association member and one (1) Support Organization member.  It is requested that the following applicants be appointed for a first term to the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee by the Board of Trustees.  Members are allowed to serve three, two year consecutive terms.
	 
Member            Representing
Bethel Kim         Student Member – Evergreen Valley College
Cory Demar       Student Member – Evergreen Valley College

Each year, the SJECCD Board of Trustees conducts a budget study session to facilitate "informed" and "data-based" decision making to guide the Chancellor and staff by providing a budget policy framework for development of the upcoming fiscal year's budget.  This study session will lead to adoption of a tentative District budget in June 14, 2016 and final budget on September 13, 2016.  The attached presentation was provided to the District Budget Committee on February 11, 2016 for review, input, vetting, and feedback.  It has subsequently been modified since this initial review.  The following are the recommended changes to existing Board Principles and recommended new Board Principles that will be part of the presentation, discussion, and Board action.
	 
	 
Principles
	 
5. Add back slowly and strategically to maximize program initiatives Manage new resource allocations or funding reductions systematically and strategically to maximize student equity and success..
	 
8. Establish a District Stabilization Fund.
•Board authority required to access.
•Access during economic downturn.
•Replenish in healthy fiscal times.
•At Budget Adoption, dedicate 50% of annual “one-time” money to District Stabilization Fund to a maximum of $500,000 annually.
•At Fiscal Year End, transfer up to $500,000 of “one-time” money, when General Fund balance finishes above 10%.
•Cap Stabilization Fund at 5% of General Fund expenditures.
	 
12.  Use data to inform decision making.
	 
13.  Seed student opportunity and access revenue (land-lease proceeds) redirecting current land-lease dollars and future land-lease dollars.
	 
14.  Financially plan and budget for total cost  of ownership, including building-related expenses and program-related expenses.
	 
15.  Develop new District Budget Allocation Model.
	 
	 
	 
It is expected that this session will be interactive with ongoing discussion, questions, and answers throughout the session.

On December 8, 2015, the Board approved the Educational Master Plans for each campus and on January 12, 2016 the Board approved the Facilities Master Plans for each campus.  Additionally, at the January 12th meeting, the Board was asked to consider strategies for funding the projects identified in these plans, with a specific focus on a potential Proposition 39 Bond Measure being placed on the ballot for the November 8, 2016 General Election.
	 
Following this discussion, the Board gave direction to the Chancellor to commission a process to hire a polling firm to conduct these services.  An initial evaluation of firms was completed followed by the selection of three of the top firms to be interviewed.  The selection committee of five reached consensus to hire Fairbank, Maslin, Maullin, Metz & Associates - FM3.
	 
In that there are two election opportunities in 2016, June and November, it was decided to fast-track the polling process so the Board could evaluate the viability of the best election cycle to serve our needs.  The polling work is still underway, final results will be presented by the FM3 representatives at the February 23rd Board meeting.
	 
Following the presentation, it is expected that the Board will discuss the results and provide guidance and direction to the Chancellor for next steps.  It is important to note, that should the data guide us, and the Board decide that a June 2016 election would best serve the District, the ballot measure language and all formal protocols calling for an election would be advanced for Board approval at the next regular meeting on March 8, 2016.  Alternatively, if a November election would seem to best serve the District, then the Board will be asked to formally take action at either the June or July 2016 Board meeting.
